In addition to periodic LEPC meetings, the Arapaho Gas Plant will conduct periodic emergency drills that involve the LEPC and emergency response organizations, and the facility will provide annual refresher training to local emergency responders regarding the hazards of regulated substances in the facility. 

MANAGEMENT SYSTEM

The Operations Senior Manager has overall responsibility for the development, implementation, and integration of the RMP. Specific responsibilities are summarized in the supporting documentation associated with this RMP.  

PLANNED CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY 

The Arapaho Gas Plant will resolve the findings and recommendations from PHAs, some of which result in modifications to the process. Recommendations from PHAs are assigned to responsible subject matter expert with appropriate due date. 

The PHA provisions serve as a tool to ensure continual evaluation of potential hazards, thereby leading to continual improvements in safety standards. 

MPLX believes that diligent compliance with our PSM Program forms the framework that allows for the continued improvement to the level of safety at the Arapaho Gas Plant.  Some of the key components of the program that will help maintain and, where applicable, improve safety are:

The Management of Change provisions ensure that the Arapaho Gas Plant considers the potential safety and health impacts of each change made to chemicals, technology, equipment or procedures.

The Mechanical Integrity provisions ensure that equipment and instrumentation are designed, constructed, installed, and maintained to minimize the risk of hazardous release thereby serving as an integral part to the safety program.

Internal and third-party compliance audits will ensure that the Arapaho Gas Plant maintains and increases the level of safety protection.

DOCUMENTATION OF CALCULATIONS WILL BE PROVIDED UPON REQUEST

YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY 

In the last five years, the Arapaho Gas Plant has had no accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in death, injury or significant property damage on site, or known off site death, injury, evacuation, sheltering in place, property damage or environmental damage. 

EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM INFORMATION 

The Arapaho Gas Plant is a Non-Responding Facility as per 48 CFR 68.90(b).  The facility maintains a written emergency action plan, which is in place to help protect employees and public safety as well as the environment.  The plan identifies steps to be taken in case of an accidental release including: evacuation plans, accounting for personnel after an evacuation, and notification of company staff, local emergency response agencies, and the public if a release occurs.  However, facility personnel are not trained to be first responders to large fires and should a release occur from one of the vessels the Arapaho Gas Plant would rely on the local fire department to respond.  

Employees receive training in the procedures to be followed when certain employees must remain to operate critical process operations before they evacuate.  The Arapaho Gas Plant has around the-clock communications capability with appropriate emergency response organizations (Fire Department, LEPC, and Sheriff's Office).  This interface provides the means of notifying the public of an incident, if necessary, as well as facilitating quick response to an incident.

The overall emergency response program for the Arapaho Gas Plant is coordinated with the Custer County Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC). This coordination includes periodic meetings of the committee, which includes local emergency response officials, local government officials, and industry representatives. 68.25 (e) for flammable worst-case release scenario. The worst-case radius to endpoint was determined utilizing RMP*Comp software provided by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA). In evaluating the worst case scenario there were no administrative controls or mitigation measures taken into account to reduce potential off-site impact. The population within the worst-case radius was determined using the Missouri Census Data Center.

Several vessels within the facility process were evaluated for their release scenarios.  Results of the worst-case release scenarios indicate that the process is subject to RMP Program Level 1 requirements.  Details of the worst-case release scenario are included with the backup documentation associated with this RMP Plan.

Based on the criteria in 40 CFR 68.10, the distance to the specified endpoint for the worst-case accidental release scenario for the following process(es) is less than the distance to the nearest public receptor: MPLX Arapaho Plant. Within the past five years, the process(es) has (have) had no accidental release that caused offsite impacts provided in the risk management program rule (40 CFR 68.10(g)(1)). No additional measures are necessary to prevent offsite impacts from accidental releases. In the event of fire, explosion, or a release of a regulated substance from the process(es), entry within the distance to the specified endpoints may pose a danger to public emergency responders. Therefore, public emergency responders should not enter this area except as arranged with the emergency contact indicated in the RMP. The undersigned certifies that, to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief, formed after reasonable inquiry, the information submitted is true, accurate, and complete.

GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM 

The Arapaho Gas Plant is covered by the Occupational Health and Safety Administration (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) Program to aid in accident release prevention.

FIVE-

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY – ARAPAHO GAS PLANT 

MPLX, L.P (MPLX), owner and operator of the Arapaho Gas Plant, has a long-standing commitment to worker and public safety. This commitment is demonstrated by the resources invested in accident prevention, such as training personnel and considering safety in the design, installation, operation, and maintenance of our processes. Our policy is to implement reasonable controls to prevent foreseeable releases of regulated substances. However, if a release does occur, facility trained personnel will respond to control and contain the release. 

DESCRIPTION OF THE STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCES 

The Arapaho Plant is located 9 miles North of Butler, Oklahoma in Custer County.  The facility processes raw gas from a field gathering system. Produced natural gas is brought into the plant via the inlet slug catchers which separate condensate from the natural gas stream. The Arapaho Gas Plant’s primary activity is the extraction of natural gas liquids (NGL) from a natural gas stream through the operation of a cryogenic expander unit.  Other processes at the site include compression, dehydration, and carbon dioxide removal to meet specifications for sales.  Regulated substances at the facility are a flammable mixture of NGL which is separated from the natural gas stream, and propane used in the refrigeration process. The NGL product is transported from the plant by truck.

The products at the Arapaho Gas Plant contain methane, ethane, propane, butanes, pentanes, and heavier hydrocarbon components. The regulated flammable substances include the same methane through pentane components. This facility does not handle regulated toxic substances above their threshold quantities and there are no toxic release scenarios to consider.
